titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck, October 1, 1896
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
titleStmt.sponsor: Supported in part by a grant from the Wyoming Cultural Trust Fund, a program of the Department of State Parks and Cultural Resources.

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

notesStmt.note: BBWW performed in Muscatine, Iowa, on October 1, 1896. The Paxton-Gallagher business became renowned for its line of wholesale groceries including Butternut coffee. Paxton & Gallagher Wholesale Grocery Company was founded in 1879 by William Paxton and Benjamin Gallagher. 'Buffalo partners' are investors from Buffalo, N.Y., including Rumsey and Bleistein.

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck

msIdentifier.repository: University of Wyoming, American Heritage Center, Buffalo Bill Letters to George T. Beck (Acc. #9972)

div1.note:
Buffalo Bill's Wild West and Congress of Rough Riders.
of the World.
Col. W. F. Cody. (Buffalo Bill), President.
Nate Salsbury. Vice-President & Manager.
John M. Burke. General Manager.
Albert E. Sheible, Business Manager.
Jule Keen, Treasurer.
div1.p: I am fretting and cantcan't hear from you or in fact from any one from that end. CantCan't tell what you are doing. The last I heard from any of you— Paxton & Gallagher3 wired me to go security for annotheranother bill of goods. Saying $1.306 past due. Buffalo partners4 refuse absolutely to do nothing. As I have written time and again— I have no idea what you are doing

postscript.p:
PS—
Suppose you have closed down. As I get no more daily reports. Would have thanked some one if they had told me—

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Muscatine, Iowa, on October 1, 1896.
Note 2: The year is not inscribed by Cody but is 1896.
Note 3: Paxton & Gallagher Wholesale Grocery Company was founded in Omaha in 1879 by William Paxton and Benjamin Gallagher.
Note 4: "Buffalo partners" are the investors from Buffalo, N. Y., including Bleistein, Rumsey, and Gerrans.
